awd_titl_txt: Extracting the RING from the B-box: Characterizing MID1 B-box1 E3 ligase activity
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Michael Massiah from the George Washington University to investigate factors that contribute to the function of a key class of enzymes involved in cellular protein recycling. All living organisms employ a common mechanism to maintain protein concentration and function to ensure a normal cell life cycle. A protein marked for recycling is covalently modified with a protein called ubiquitin (Ub). Proteins with multiple Ubs are cleaved into small fragments. The class of proteins that facilitates protein Ub modification are called RING E3 enzymes, and they are overall similar in structure. However, each RING E3 marks a specific set of proteins for modification. Despite structural similarity, the basis for substrate specificity and varying levels of activities by E3s are unknown. With this project, graduate, undergraduate and high school students re-engineer a new class of E3 enzyme and determine how specific amino acid changes affect the enzyme function. Students gain important biotechnology skills and the use of numerous chemical tools to characterize protein structure and protein-protein interactions. 
 
This research project focuses on the B-box1 domain from the MID1 protein. This new class of Ub E3 enzymes has the same overall structure as RING E3 but exhibits a much lower level of activity. Through the use of PCR-based mutagenesis, specific amino acids of the B-box1 domain are changed. Multi-dimensional nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy is utilized to determine the structures of the various mutants of the B-box1 domain, and used to characterize their interactions with an E2 enzyme that is part of the ubiquitination cascade. Isothermal titration calorimetry, fluorescence spectroscopy, and FTIR are among the tools employed to characterize binding interactions. Completion of this project leads to identification of amino acids and structural features important for E3 ligase activity and substrate binding. These findings can be applied to other B-box domains and RING E3s to predict activity and mechanism of action.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The B-box1 domain is a small approximately 50-60 amino acid protein domain that has been identified in plant and mammalian proteins. Very little is known about their mechanism of function. We have recently solved the structure of the B-box1 domain from the human MID1 protein and observed that it binds two zinc ions via a cross-brace mechanism and adopts a beta-beta-alpha fold that is common to the zinc-binding RING domains. RING domains are shown to function as ubiquitin E3 ligases, facilitating the modification of proteins with ubiquitin, a small stable protein. Ubiquitinated proteins are typically targeted to and by the cell’s proteasome for degradation and recycling.  RING-type E3 ligases represent the largest group of E3 ligases that facilitate protein regulation via degradation. The B-box1 domain represents a new member to the RING-type family.

 

  Intellectual Impact: Despite having a similar RING-like fold, the MID1 B-box1 domain exhibits monoubiquitination activity, compared to the polyubiquitination activity commonly observed with RING E3 ligases. The project focuses on deciphering why the B-box1 domain exhibits such activity. We hypothesized that its interaction with the ubiquitin E2 conjugating enzyme (E2) impacts its activity.  Indeed, NMR studies revealed that the B-box1 interacted on a distinct surface of Ube2d1 (cognate E2) different from RING E3 domain binding sites. The structure explains the monoubiquitination product because the site of interaction precludes a non-covalent interaction between Ube2d1 and a ubiquitin that is necessary for chain elongation (polyubiquitination). The interaction shows that the B-box1 domain would also prevent the covalently linked ubiquitin to be more in the open conformation in its interaction with the Ube2d1 enzyme; the open conformation is important for rate of ubiquitination. Isothermal calorimetry (ITC) studies revealed that the B-box1 domain bound Ube2d1 with a similar binding affinity as the MID1 RING domain suggesting that the strength of the interaction did not impact the rate. The rate of thiolysis (Ub and Ube2d1 cleavage) was greatest with the MID1 RING domain compared with the B-box1 domain indicating weaker allosteric effect, consistent with the monoubiquitination activity observed. Altering the structure of the B-box1 domain by changing several amino acids increased its E3 activity. The P151L mutation resulted in a B-box1 domain that is significantly more active, exhibiting polyubiquitination activity. Similar structural and binding studies revealed that its binding site is different from that of the wild-type B-box1 domain. The binding site is closer to where RING E3 domains binds and this supports the increase allosteric effect observed.

       Broader Impact: These studies demonstrate for the first time the mechanism of action of a B-box1 domain, which represents a new class of RING-type E3 ligases. These studies lead to the first structure of an E2 enzyme with a B-box1 domain. Importantly, these studies suggest that how an E3 domain interact with the E2 enzyme impacts its allosteric influence on thiolysis and ubiquitination activity. The location of loop2 of the RING-fold is important for activity, as demonstrated with the P151L mutation. Key results were published in scientific journals, and additionally disseminated via scientific talks, poster sessions and in the academic classroom. Outreach: Twenty-one students were engaged with this project: one was a female post-doc, two female graduate students, 16 undergraduate students (10 female, one Native American, one African-American, two REU), and three high school students (1 female). Of the individuals who have graduated, all have maintained careers in research or medicine. This project has served well in preparing students for careers in STEM fields.

 


Last Modified: 09/07/2023
Modified by: Michael A Massiah
